chapter: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question: Question 1: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS?
questions.explanation:
The time interval between primary HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS is 10 years. After exposure to the HIV virus, there occurs primary infection following an incubation period of 
2-4 weeks, which is usually symptomatic in more than 50% of cases, following 3-6 weeks there is 
acute HIV syndrome due to wide dissemination of the virus, characterized by fever, sore throat, 
diarrhea, lymphadenopathy, and rash. This peak viremia drops as the immune response develops, to reach a plateau about 3 months 
later. Following this there is a prolonged period of clinical latency, during which infected 
individuals are asymptomatic, lasting for a median of 10 years. 1483 
Sold by @itachibot Following this period, chronic persistent infection develops which is the hallmark of HIV disease 
called Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Long-term non-progressors: a small part of untreated HIV-infected people with CD4 counts 
within the reference range for >10 years. Elite controllers: Some long-term non-progressors have undetectable viral loads.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following case scenarios depict a mode of transmission that carries the highest 
risk of acquiring HIV?

options.a: A 23-year-old drug addict sharing syringes during intravenous drug abuse
options.b: A 15-year-old thalassemic adolescent undergoing blood transfusion
options.c: A 30-year-old man engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners
options.d: A 27-year-old nurse accidentally injuring herself while drawing blood

questions.explanation:
Blood transfusion carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV. Salient features of transmission of HIV: • The highest risk of acquiring HIV from an infected source is via blood transfusion > needle 
sharing during drug abuse > receptive anal intercourse > needle-stick injury > vaginal 
& oral sexual intercourse. • The most common mode of transmission worldwide is sexual transmission (heterosexual in 
India) > mother to child > least common modes are blood transfusion & needle-stick 
injury. • Male to female transmission > female to male transmission. • Viral load is highest in blood > semen > vaginal fluid > breastmilk & saliva and 
minimal to absent in tears, sweat & urine.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question: Question 3: Which statement regarding HIV infection is true?

options.a: HIV-2 is more pathogenic than HIV -1
options.b: HIV-1 subtype C is the most common form worldwide
options.d: Donated blood is not screened for HIV- 2

questions.explanation:
HIV-1 subtype C is the most common form worldwide. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has two serotypes HIV-1 and HIV- 2 based on differences 
in the env (envelope) gene. HIV-1 is further divided into 4 distinct groups, group M (major)/N/O/P. The M group comprises 
nine subtypes A, B, C, D, F, G, H, J, and K. • Subtype C is the most common form worldwide & is more associated with heterosexual 
transmission. • Subtype B is more associated with spread through blood and homosexual contact. Options A, C: HIV- 2 is less pathogenic than HIV-1 and is predominantly confined to Africa. Option D: Donated blood is screened for both HIV -1 & HIV-2.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 4: A 47-year-old phlebotomist suffered a needle-stick injury while drawing blood from a patient 
with HIV. Which of the following mutations in him can cause a resistance to acquiring HIV 
infection?
questions.explanation:
CCR 5 delta 32 mutation causes resistance to HIV infection. It is a mutated allele that causes a 
lack of surface expression of the CCR5 co-receptor resulting in blockade of HIV entry and 1484 
Sold by @itachibot resistance to HIV infection. Homozygous alleles cause complete resistance to HIV infection & heterozygous alleles cause 
partial resistance. CXCR4 and CCR5 are chemokine receptors (co-receptors) present on the surface of CD4+ 
T-helper cells & macrophages that aid in the fusion and entry of the HIV virus. DC-SIGN is a type of cell surface lectin receptor to which the HIV virus has the affinity to bind. 
The expression of this type of receptor on dendritic cells (antigen-presenting cells) enhances the 
infectivity of HIV.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 5: A 19-year-old woman presents to the casualty with a 24-hour history of fever, sore throat, and 
diffuse erythematous macular rash. Past history is positive for unprotected intercourse with a 
new partner. What is true about the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute HIV syndrome. The virus is transmissible during 
this early infection period. It is characterized by acute burst of viremia and wide virus dissemination and seeding of 
lymphoid organs (e.g., gut-associated lymphoid tissue), culminating in the destruction of CD4+ 
cells. The p24 antigen capture assay is used as a screening test for HIV infection in patients suspected 
of having the acute HIV syndrome. Option A: The incubation period for acute HIV syndrome is around 3 to 6 weeks. Option B: The acute HIV syndrome is typical of an acute viral syndrome and is very similar to 
acute infectious mononucleosis. The clinical findings include fever, sore throat, and 
lymphadenopathy. Rash, headache, arthralgia, and anorexia/weight loss can also be seen. Option D: Opportunistic infections can occur during this stage of infection, reflecting the 
immunodeficiency that results from reduced numbers of CD4+T cells.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 6: What is the correct WHO staging for an HIV-infected child with unexplained persistent 
parotid enlargement?
questions.explanation:
Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement in an HIV-infected child is categorized as stage 2 of 
HIV disease according to WHO staging. 1485 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.explanation:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO stage 3. Oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia are oral lesions categorized as WHO clinical stage 3. 
They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/L. The image given below shows a patient with oral hairy leukoplakia. Oral candidiasis

questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals?
questions.explanation:
Tuberculosisis the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals globally and 
in India. In patients with relatively high CD4+ T cell counts, the typical pattern of pulmonary reactivation 
occurs (60–80%). In patients with lower CD4+ T cell counts, disseminated disease is seen. Primary prophylaxis: Isoniazid and pyridoxine for 9 months for HIV-infected individuals meeting 
the following conditions: • PPD skin-test reaction of >5 mm or, • Positive IFN- release assay or, • Close household contacts of persons with active tuberculosis
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 9: A previously untreated HIV-positive patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis and treatment is 
initiated for both the diseases. Two weeks into treatment, he suddenly complains of high 
fever, severe malaise and worsening cough. What is the likely explanation?

options.c: Bacterial endotoxin release due to death of TB bacilli

questions.explanation:
Concurrent treatment with anti-retroviral therapy is the most likely explanation in this case 
resulting in Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Its characteristics are: • Temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms (lymphadenopathy, fever or worsening of 
pulmonary infiltrations, pleural effusion) and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting 
ART. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART 
and ATT. • It is seen weeks to months following the initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART). • It is most common in previously untreated patients starting therapy with a CD4+ T cell count 
<50/L who experience a sudden drop in viral load. 1487 
Sold by @itachibot • The earlier ART is started and the lower the baseline CD4+ T-cell count, the greater the risk of 
IRIS. • In severe cases, the use of immunosuppressive drugs such as glucocorticoids may be required to 
blunt the inflammatory component of IRIS while specific antimicrobial therapy takes effect. Note: Hypersensitivity to isoniazid is extremely rare and the presentation includes maculopapular 
rash.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 10: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following 
finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the 
most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. 
Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally 
occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/L. Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show 
modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is 
usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure). The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans 
yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex 
agglutination (CrAg). Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/L. Treatment: • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with 
amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative. • Maintenance - Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/L for 
6 months in response to cART.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question: Question 11: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except :
questions.explanation:
Melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy. AIDS-defining malignancies are those cancers that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) 
infected person is at a high risk of developing. When a HIV-infected person develops one of the 
AIDS-defining malignancies it suggests that he has AIDS. AIDS-defining malignancies include the following: • Kaposi sarcoma - It is a multicentric neoplasm of vascular origin and has a strong association 
with HHV - 8. • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma • Invasive cervical cancer Given below is the image of kaposi sarcoma: 1488 
Sold by @itachibot Note : The FDA has approved pomalidomide, a thalidomide analogue to be included in treating 
adult patients with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma after failure of highly active antiretroviral 
therapy and Kaposi's sarcoma in adult patients who are HIV-negative.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 12: 1478 
Sold by @itachibot A 45-year-old HIV-positive woman presented with fever and malaise. She gives a history of 
bleeding from the following lesions. Warthin-Starry staining of a biopsy sample taken from 
the lesion showed which organism?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis in an immunocompromised 
patient. Warthin-Starry stain would show Bartonella henselae as the causative organism in these 
skin lesions. Bacillary angiomatosis is an infectious vascular proliferative lesion presenting as reddish-purple 
nodules similar to KS lesions (caused by HHV-8). The diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The 
drug of choice for treatment is erythromycin. The image given below shows the Warthin-Starry stained lesion showing tangled pleomorphic 
bacilli. 1489 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: HHV 8 is strongly associated with Kaposi sarcoma. Option C: Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever. Option D: EBV causes infectious mononucleosis. Note: Bartonella henselae causes cat-scratch disease, a necrotizing granulomatous disorder of 
lymph nodes, in immunocompetent hosts.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 13: An HIV-positive woman was rushed to the ICU following an episode of generalized 
tonic-clonic seizures. There was no history of fever, night sweats or weight loss. MRI scan is 
shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 1479 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple 
ring-enhancing lesions. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections 
and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/L. It is usually a reactivation of 
latent tissue cysts. It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and 
central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric 
nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical 
of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present. Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell 
count <100/L. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is 
given. Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/L. 
Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts 
are maintained >200/L for 6 months. Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, 
headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI 1490 
Sold by @itachibot findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts. Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological 
deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On 
imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 
hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted 
diffusion. Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by 
demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white 
matter lesions.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question: Question 14: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.explanation:
Oral candidiasis, although seen in AIDS patients, is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of 
the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, and lungs are AIDS-defining illnesses. AIDS-defining illnesses are specific opportunistic illnesses in patients with AIDS, which signify an 
advanced stage of illness (Stage 3). A case of HIV can be classified into five stages as per current CDC guidelines (0, 1, 2, 3, and 
unknown). Criteria 
CD4+ count (>5 year 
s) Stag 
e 0 
A negative HIV test within 6 
months of first diagnosis NA 1 
Based on CD4+ count 
>=500 2 
Based on CD4+ count 
200-499 3 
AIDS-defining opportunistic i 
llness <200 Unavailable CD4+ counts 
unknown unkn 
own
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 15: An HIV-positive woman was referred to the ophthalmology OPD for decreased visual acuity. 
She described her vision as blurry with apparent flies floating in her field of vision. 
Fundoscopy revealed the following finding. What is the CD4+T cell count at which majority of 
such cases occur? 1480 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, along with the pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy, is suggestive of 
cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. The majority of such cases occur in HIV-infected patients with a 
CD4+T cell count <50/L. CMV retinitis is a necrotic retinal infection that results in a painless irreversible vision loss. 
Patients may complain of blurred vision, floaters (described by patient as flies or spiders in the 
field of vision), and scintillations. It is usually bilateral and is characterized by perivascular 
hemorrhage and exudates in the retina (pizza pie appearance or scrambled eggs and ketchup 
appearance). 1491 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment: • Induction - IV ganciclovir (3 weeks) • Maintenance - Oral valganciclovir (till CD4 count > 100/l for 6months)
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 16: A unemployed HIV-positive patient, resident of a missionary home, presents with 2 weeks of 
fever, cough and night sweats. He was devastated after getting fired from his job because of 
his diagnosis and has since been non-compliant to cART. His CD4 count is <10/ L. CT 
scan shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? 1481 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. It is 
an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T cell counts of 
<50/L. The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and night sweats. 
The diagnosis is made by culture of blood or involved tissue. CT scan shows peribronchial inflammation of the infected lung giving rise to a tree in a bud 
appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures) indicated by the arrowhead. In 
severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation. Treatment consists of clarithromycin / azithromycin with ethambutol/ rifabutin. Primary 
prophylaxis with azithromycin is indicated in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <50/L.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question:
Question 17: A 50-year-old man with HIV presents with lab reports showing: Low albumin, massive 
proteinuria. Renal ultrasound shows large, echogenic kidneys. Blood pressure is normal. 
Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
This patient with HIV presents with massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. The most likely 
cause is HIV-1-associated nephropathy (HIVAN) - a form of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis 
(FSGS). Proteinuria is the hallmark of this disorder. Edema and hypertension are rare. A definitive 
diagnosis is obtained through renal biopsy.
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is the most common form of heart disease associated with HIV?
questions.explanation:
The most common form of heart disease associated with HIV infection is coronary heart disease. In patients with HIV infection, cardiovascular disease may be a direct consequence of HIV 
infection, a complication of anti-retroviral therapy or due to classical risk factors like smoking. Exposure to HIV protease inhibitors and reverse transcriptase inhibitors have been associated 
with an increase in total cholesterol and/or risk of MI (Myocardial infarction). Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with congestive heart failure (CHF) is referred to as 
HIV-associated cardiomyopathy. This generally occurs as a late complication of HIV infection and, 
histologically, displays elements of myocarditis. 1492 
Sold by @itachibot HIV / AIDS - Management and Prophylaxis
questions.chapter_heading: HIV   AIDS - Epidemiology and Clinical Features
